subChapters.fullItemName: When should I screen for HIV?
subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I offer a test for HIV?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Offer an HIV test in primary care (or where appropriate direct to specialist services for testing) people who:
    • Request testing — the person may not be prepared to discuss their risks so avoid discouraging those with no apparent risk.
    • Have risk factors for HIV.
    • Have another sexually transmitted infection.
    • Have an indicator condition or clinical features of HIV infection.
    • Are newly registered with general practice or are having a blood test, if they have not had an HIV test in the past 12 months, in areas of the UK where diagnosed prevalence of HIV is high (greater than 2 per 1000 population aged 15–59 years) — annually updated HIV prevalence data by locality is available from the Public Health England website.
  • All pregnant women should be offered screening for HIV as part of routine antenatal care.
  • All children at risk of HIV infection should have an HIV test.
    • Testing for children at risk of HIV should be urgently discussed with at least one of the child’s parents or legal guardians, and appropriate testing and follow up arranged with specialist paediatric HIV services.
  • For information on what to include in the pre-test and post-test discussion:
    • See the section on How to test for HIV.
  • If a venous blood sample is declined:
    • Offer a less invasive form of specimen collection, such as a mouth swab or finger prick.
  • If the person chooses not to take up an immediate offer of a test:
    • Advise them on nearby testing services and how to get self-sampling kits.
      • Self-sampling HIV kits allow people to collect their own sample of blood or saliva and send it by post for testing and can be requested online via www.freetesting.hiv.
      • Several organizations, such as the Terence Higgins Trust (an HIV/AIDS charity) provide local information on testing services including self-testing (www.tht.org.uk).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Recommendations are based on the clinical guidelines UK National guidelines for HIV testing [BHIVA, 2008b], HIV in primary care. A practical guide for primary healthcare professionals in Europe [Matthews, 2016], HIV testing: increasing uptake among people who may have undiagnosed HIV [NICE, 2016], CHIVA standards of care for infants, children, and young people with HIV (including infants born to mothers with HIV) [CHIVA, 2017], and Standards of care for people living with HIV [BHIVA, 2018a]; the Public Health England report HIV in the United Kingdom. Towards zero HIV transmissions by 2030 [PHE, 2019b]; and expert opinion in review articles [Kirkham, 2017; Bamford, 2018; BMJ Best Practice, 2020a].

Update to BHIVA guidance on HIV testing

  • At the time of writing (July 2020) the British HIV Association (BHIVA) Guidelines Subcommittee, the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) Clinical Effectiveness Group and the British Infection Association (BIA) Adult HIV Testing Guidelines (2020) were in the process of being updated.

Testing of children at risk of HIV

  • Children (in particular infants) with HIV infection are at high risk of rapid disease progression [CHIVA, 2017] — early diagnosis and initiation of antiretroviral therapy are essential in prevention of serious morbidity and mortality.

Testing of people registered at general practices in areas of high prevalence

  • National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance on HIV testing [NICE, 2016] recommends:
    • Annual testing of people in groups or communities with a high rate of HIV, and more frequently if a person is at high risk of exposure.
    • In areas where HIV prevalence is high, that HIV testing is offered to all people who have not previously been diagnosed with HIV who are newly registering with a practice and those who have not had a HIV test in the previous year. Testing should be offered at each consultation in areas of extremely high prevalence.
      • A high prevalence area is defined as a local authority with a diagnosed HIV prevalence of 2–5 per 1000 people aged 15–59 years.
      • An extremely high prevalence area is defined as a local authority with a diagnosed HIV prevalence of 5 or more per 1000 people aged 15–59 years.
